newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnia's vital winter gas supply in doubt.
newsitem.headline: Bosnia's vital winter gas supply in doubt.

text.p: Bosnians may shiver through the winter unless the government and a local gas company reach agreement with a Russian gas supplier on an outstanding $11 million debt, a company manager said on Thursday.
Gas is an important source of heating in a country striving to recover from a 43-month war but haggling over payment of the debt has put the winter gas supply in doubt.
In addition to the $11 million dating from October last year, Bosnia accumulated a $105-million debt during the war, which was put aside for separate negotiations with London and Paris debt clubs.

The Russian supplier "Gas Export" says it will only provide gas until the end of the year unless Bosnia presents a plan to pay the existing debt and for future supplies, said Mensur Causevic, deputy-director of the country's gas importer, Energoinvest.
Energoinvest, which describes itself as a Bosnian engineering group, has requested the government's help in solving the debt problem but Causevic said it has received little help so far.
"We organised a meeting on Saturday, but none of the government officials who could solve the debt problem showed up," Causevic told Reuters.
Bosnian officials say the gas problem comes at a time when a post-war government is still being formed, with newly-elected officials just taking up their jobs.
"My government is no longer responsible for that, you should speak to the (Moslem-Croat) federation's government," Bosnia's outgoing Prime Minister Hasan Muratovic said.
"There is no need to dramatise the situation, we shall not freeze this winter."
Muratovic has proposed alternatives to gas heating, saying local resources such as electricity and coal should be used more often.
"I've always said gas should be a substitute, not a primary source of power," he said.

But critics say such a solution could hit people's wallets severely. Bosnia's war-ravaged electricity system is not to be trusted either and could collapse with a sharp rise in power consumption, they say.
A cold November spell increased gas use, creating shortages and also underlined the need to arrange a long-term agreement with the Russian gas company.
One Western official said he did not believe the Russians would cut the gas supply off altogether and viewed their tough stance as "payment posturing from Moscow".

Muratovic said two proposals were being considered. One plan involved equal payments from the state budget, foreign donors and users and the other proposal would draw on the World Bank's $90 million of transitional credit for reconstruction.
Meanwhile, Bosnia's electric company offered special discounts to people opting for electric heating.
